newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australians give up booze and smokes to live longer.
newsitem.headline: Australians give up booze and smokes to live longer.

text.p: Australians are getting thinner, drinking less alcohol, smoking less -- and living longer for it.

A survey released on Thursday by the Australian Bureau of Statistics said women were living to an average age of 81 in 1995, up from 79 a decade before. Men were living, on average, to 75 compared with 72.
"Tobacco and alcohol consumption have been declining as has our consumption of fats which have helped to increase our life expectancy," the ABS said.

The survey, based on 1995 figures, said average daily alcohol consumption fell to 27 ml per adult from 31.5 ml in 1985 and tobacco consumption fell to 4.3 grams a day from 6.7. Daily fat intake fell to 52.2 grams a person in 1993, the last year the question was asked, from 57.5 grams.
As Australians cut back on their smoking, drinking and fatty foods, they have been getting into better shape.
Only 32 percent were overweight, compared with 37 percent a decade earlier.
The bureau said Australia's already low mortality rates were were continuing to fall through better healthcare and lifestyle.

"This decline is mainly due to advances in medical technology and the leading of healthier life styles through better diet, regular exercise and reductions in tobacco and alcohol consumption," it said. The overall annual death rate fell to 646 per 100,000 people in 1995 from 816 in 1985.
Cancer remained the biggest killer of Australians, killing 178 per 100,000 people per year, compared with 186.
But there was a dramatic fall in deaths from heart disease over the decade, to 151 per 100,000 from 225.
